awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Surface Plasmon Resonance Microscopy System for Interdisciplinary Research and Research Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs. Professor Yixian Wang from California State University Los Angeles and colleagues Jamil Momand, Edith Porter, Jing Zhao, as well as Fangyuan Tian from California State University Long Beach have acquired a surface plasmon resonance microscope (SPRM). This microscope can be used to study, for example, how proteins bind to the membrane of a single cell. The microscope operates by shining a light source at a sensor chip or metal plate. The light interacts with the metal plate to excite electrons and modify the light which is reflected to a detector. This is the so-called surface plasmon signal. When a sample to be studied is added, the surface plasmon signal is changed and data such as the interaction of a protein with a cell membrane can be evaluated. This technique can also be used to study how nanomaterials interact with cancer cells. It can shed light on drug delivery systems. Other applications range from environmental science to food quality and safety. The instrument is used by undergraduates and graduate student in their research projects providing training in future careers in chemical and biological analysis. This is the first SPRM instrument in the Los Angeles area.  

The award of this surface plasmon resonance microscope is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially aids studies of protein binding kinetics studies at multiple and single cell membranes and the search for real-time interaction between antimicrobial effector molecules and bacterial surfaces. The microscope is essential for the exploration of medicine delivery on iron-containing metal-organic framework thin films and for engineering nanomaterials interaction and uptake in cells. It also helps investigators in the determination of real-time electrochemical, redox active species release from cells and protein arrays during exocytosis and in rice protein arrays.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This MRI grant acquired a new surface plasmon resonance microscopy (SPRM) system that has offered new valuable interdisciplinary research and research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at California State University Los Angeles and California State University Long Beach. 

The acquired SPRM system combines the novel microscopy technique with binding kinetics studies in the fields of chemistry, biochemistry, biology, microbiology, materials science, and food science. It has helped the five participating faculty develop new research directions and collaborations and achieve deeper understanding in the underlying molecular mechanisms within multiple interdisciplinary research areas.

(1) In the area of protein binding kinetics studies at multiple and single cell membranes, the Wang group studied the alpha-synuclein (α-Syn) and dopaminergic neuron interaction and subsequent cell disruption. This work provided a possible mechanism for α-Syn permeabilizing SH-SY5Y cell membranes. Drs. Momand and Wang collaborated on the measurement of the affinity of Herceptin to Her2, its natural target in the breast cancer, on four breast cancer cell lines, each expressing t-Darpp or an altered version of the t-Darpp (mutant). The results indicate that t-Darpp overexpression does reduce the effectiveness of Herceptin and suggest that clinicians should consider screening for t-Darpp overexpression in biopsies obtained from breast cancer patients.

(2) In the field of microbiology, the Porter and Wang groups developed protocols to measure the real-time interaction between antimicrobial effector molecules and bacterial surfaces and will provide new insight in the activity of two epithelial beta- defensins, HBD2 and HBD3, applied alone and in combination with liposomal formulations of cholesteryl lineolate and cholertseryl arachidonate. Importantly, a protocol has been designed to measure binding to live bacteria.

(3) In the field of advanced materials, the Tian group studied drug delivery on iron-containing metal-organic framework thin films. This project studied the molecular interactions between a model drug (ibuprofen) and the carrier material (MIL-88B). The SPRM results confirmed that the ibuprofen releasing was associated with the degradation of MIL-88B particles.

(4) In the field of electrochemistry, the Wang group used SPRM to image individual nanoparticles (NPs) and revealed the correlation between their surface structures and the electrochemical activities. We also ﻿demonstrated the capability of investigating electrochemical reactions at Prussian blue nanoparticles and their sensing capability to reactive oxygen species, such as H2O2, at the single nanoparticle level. The Zhao group explored the possibility of using electrochemical techniques in the study of protein oxidation and achieved some preliminary success in establishing a linear relationship between the amperometric signal and the concentrations of reactive oxygen species such as hydrogen peroxide.

Results from the above projects have been disseminated to communities of interest through presentations in local and national conferences such as CSUPERB symposiums, SACNAS conference, ACS conferences, and Gordon Research Conferences. Five papers have been published with undergraduate and graduate student coauthors, one submitted, and four currently in preparation. The preliminary data acquired with the new SPRM system also helped the PI to receive the NIH R15 award (2020, R15 NS120157-01), NSF CAREER award (2021, CHE-2045839) and the co-PI Dr. Tian to receive an NIH SCORE (2020, SC3GM136590).

The acquisition of the SPRM has resulted in a significant and essential upgrade to the research experiences offered to students. Seventeen undergraduate and eight graduate students have been directly assigned to the associated projects with all of them having access to the instrument. Six of them have chosen to continue their STEM research in advanced graduate programs. Additional students benefit from the instrument through research training courses, such as a workshop at CSULB for training undergraduate students on SPR(M) and quartz crystal microbalance to study molecular interactions on functionalized gold surfaces. The requested SPRM has unleashed the field of molecular binding/interaction to five participating faculty with multidisciplinary background from two institutions, strengthened existing and created new interdisciplinary collaborations among chemists, materials and life scientists, and food scientists, and generate novel protocols and exciting findings within the proposed research areas. Two junior faculty of this team have obtained their tenure and one of them has received an NSF Career Award.
